code: library(tteICE) data(bmt) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) X = as.matrix(bmt[,c('z1','z3','z5')]) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "natural") plot_inc(fit1, plot.configs=list(legend=c('AML','ALL'))) plot_ate(fit1) ## We can also use bootstrap confidence intervals # plot_ate(fit1, nboot=200) fit2 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "natural", X, method='ipw') plot_inc(fit2, plot.configs=list(legend=c('AML','ALL'))) plot_ate(fit2) fit3 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "natural", X, method='eff') plot_inc(fit3, plot.configs=list(legend=c('AML','ALL'))) plot_ate(fit3)

text: x fitted object returned function surv.tteICE scr.tteICE. type plot create: ate indicates plot estimated treatment effect; inc indicates plot estimated cumulative incidence function. decrease logical variable indicating type curve display. decrease = FALSE (default), function displays cumulative incidence functions (CIFs) differences. decrease = TRUE, function instead displays survival functions differences. conf.int Confidence level interval. conf.int = NULL, confidence interval provided. xlab Label x-axis. xlim numeric vector length 2 giving limits x-axis. xlim=NULL (default), range determined automatically data. ylim numeric vector length 2 giving limits y-axis. ylim=NULL (default), range determined automatically type plot plot.configs named list additional plot configurations. See details functions  plot_ate plot_inc ... augments function plot.default function curve

title: Graphical results of tteICE — plot.tteICE
text: Plot results tteICE object

title: Graphical results of tteICE — plot.tteICE
code: ## load data data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) ## plot cumulative incidence functions with p-values for (st in c('composite','natural','removed','whileon','principal')){  fit = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, st)  plot(fit, type="inc", decrease=TRUE, ylim=c(0,1),       plot.configs=list(show.p.value=TRUE)) }      ## plot treatment effects for semicompeting risk data for (st in c('composite','natural','removed','whileon','principal')){  fit = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, st)  plot(fit, type="ate", ylim=c(-1,1), xlab="time",       plot.configs=list(col="red")) }

title: Plot the estimated treatment effect — plot_ate
code: ## Load data and fit the model data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) ## Model with competing risk data fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, 'composite') ## Plot asymptotic confidence intervals based on explicit formulas plot_ate(fit1, ylim=c(-0.4,0.4))  # \donttest{ ## Plot bootstrap confidence intervals fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, 'composite', nboot=200) plot_ate(fit1, ylim=c(-0.4,0.4))  # } ## Model with semicompeting risk data fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "composite") ## Plot asymptotic confidence intervals based on explicit formulas plot_ate(fit2, ylim=c(-0.4,0.4),          plot.configs=list(add.null.line=FALSE))  ## Plot bootstrap confidence intervals fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "composite", nboot=200) plot_ate(fit2, ylim=c(-0.4,0.4),          plot.configs=list(add.null.line=FALSE, lty=2, main=""))

title: Plot the estimated cumulative incidence function (CIF) — plot_inc
code: ## load data and fit the model data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) ## Model with competing risk data fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, 'treatment') ## plot asymptotic confidence intervals based on explicit formulas plot_inc(fit1, ylim=c(0,1),          plot.configs=list(legend=c('AML','ALL'), show.p.value=FALSE) )  # \donttest{ ## plot bootstrap confidence intervals fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, 'treatment', nboot=200) plot_inc(fit1, ylim=c(0,1),          plot.configs=list(legend=c('AML','ALL')) )  # } ## Model with semicompeting risk data fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "composite") ## plot asymptotic confidence intervals based on explicit formulas plot_inc(fit2, ylim=c(0,1), plot.configs=list(add.null.line=FALSE))  ## plot bootstrap confidence intervals fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "composite", nboot=200) plot_inc(fit2, ylim=c(0,1),          plot.configs=list(lty=2, lwd=3,main="Title"))

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event data with intercurrent events for semicompeting risks data — scr.tteICE
text: Background Intercurrent events refer events occurring treatment initiation clinical trials affect either interpretation existence measurements associated clinical question interest. International Conference Harmonization (ICH) E9 (R1) addendum proposed five strategies address intercurrent events, namely, treatment policy strategy, composite variable strategy, treatment strategy, hypothetical strategy, principal stratum strategy. answer specific scientific question, strategy particular estimand chosen study design. Model adopt potential outcomes framework defines causal estimand contrast functionals potential outcomes. Consider randomized controlled trial \(n\) individuals randomly assigned one two treatment conditions, denoted \(w\), \(w = 1\) represents active treatment (test drug) \(w = 0\) represents control (placebo). Assume patients adhere treatment assignments discontinue treatment. Associated individual \(= 1, ..., n\) two potential time--event primary outcomes \(T_i(1)\) \(T_i(0)\), , represent time durations treatment initiation primary outcome event two treatment assignments respectively. Let \(R_i(1)\) \(R_i(0)\) denote occurrence time potential intercurrent events, , two treatment assignments, respectively. Intercurrent events considered absent post-treatment intercurrent events occur end study. Estimand adopt potential cumulative incidences treatment assignments target estimands. Potential cumulative incidences describe probability time--event outcomes occurring time point. define treatment effect contrast two potential cumulative incidences. Cumulative incidences model-free collapsible, enjoying causal interpretations.

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event data with intercurrent events for semicompeting risks data — scr.tteICE
text: Deng, Y., Han, S., & Zhou, X. H. (2025). Inference Cumulative Incidences Treatment Effects Randomized Controlled Trials Time--Event Outcomes ICH E9 (R1). Statistics Medicine. doi:10.1002/sim.70091

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event data with intercurrent events for semicompeting risks data — scr.tteICE
code: ## load data data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) X = as.matrix(bmt[,c('z1','z3','z5')]) ## Composite variable strategy, ## nonparametric estimation without covariates fit1 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "composite") fit10 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "aa") ## warning message #> Warning: Please choose a strategy from the following: #>  treatment, composite, natural, removed, whileon, principal #>  #>             composite variable strategy is used by default ## Hypothetical strategy (natural effects), ## nonparametric estimation with inverse probability weighting fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "natural", X, method='ipw') ## nonparametric estimation with weights as non-standardized inverse probability score ps = predict(glm(A ~ X, family='binomial'), type='response') w = A/ps + (1-A)/(1-ps) fit2 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "natural", weights=w) ## Hypothetical strategy (removing intercurrent events), ## semiparametrically efficient estimation with covariates fit3 = scr.tteICE(A, bmt$t1, bmt$d1, bmt$t2, bmt$d2, "removed", X, method='eff')

Time Time event. cstatus Indicator event, 1 primary event, 2 intercurrent event, 0 censoring. strategy Strategy address intercurrent events, "treatment" indicating treatment policy strategy, "composite" indicating composite variable strategy, "natural" indicating hypothetical strategy (Scenario , controlling hazard intercurrent events), "removed" indicating hypothetical strategy (Scenario II, removing intercurrent events), "whileon" indicating treatment strategy, "principal" indicating principal stratum strategy. cov1 Baseline covariates. method Estimation method, "np" indicating nonparametric estimation, "np" indicating inverse treatment probability weighting, "eff" indicating semiparametrically efficient estimation based efficient influence functions. weights Weight subject. subset Subset, either numerical logical. na.rm Whether remove missing values. nboot Number resamplings boostrapping method. nboot 0 1, asymptotic standard error based explicit form calculated instead bootstrapping. seed Seed bootstrapping.

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event with intercurrent events for competing risks data — surv.tteICE
text: Background Intercurrent events refer events occurring treatment initiation clinical trials affect either interpretation existence measurements associated clinical question interest. International Conference Harmonization (ICH) E9 (R1) addendum proposed five strategies address intercurrent events, namely, treatment policy strategy, composite variable strategy, treatment strategy, hypothetical strategy, principal stratum strategy. answer specific scientific question, strategy particular estimand chosen study design. Model adopt potential outcomes framework defines causal estimand contrast functionals potential outcomes. Consider randomized controlled trial \(n\) individuals randomly assigned one two treatment conditions, denoted \(w\), \(w = 1\) represents active treatment (test drug) \(w = 0\) represents control (placebo). Assume patients adhere treatment assignments discontinue treatment. Associated individual \(= 1, ..., n\) two potential time--event primary outcomes \(T_i(1)\) \(T_i(0)\), , represent time durations treatment initiation primary outcome event two treatment assignments respectively. Let \(R_i(1)\) \(R_i(0)\) denote occurrence time potential intercurrent events, , two treatment assignments, respectively. Intercurrent events considered absent post-treatment intercurrent events occur end study. Estimand adopt potential cumulative incidences treatment assignments target estimands. Potential cumulative incidences describe probability time--event outcomes occurring time point. define treatment effect contrast two potential cumulative incidences. Cumulative incidences model-free collapsible, enjoying causal interpretations.

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event with intercurrent events for competing risks data — surv.tteICE
text: Deng, Y., Han, S., & Zhou, X. H. (2025). Inference Cumulative Incidences Treatment Effects Randomized Controlled Trials Time--Event Outcomes ICH E9 (R1). Statistics Medicine. doi:10.1002/sim.70091

title: Fit the CIF for time-to-event with intercurrent events for competing risks data — surv.tteICE
code: ## load data data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) X = as.matrix(bmt[,c('z1','z3','z5')]) ## Composite variable strategy,  ## nonparametric estimation without covariates fit1 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "composite") ## Hypothetical strategy (natural effects),  ## nonparametric estimation with inverse probability weighting fit2 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "natural", X, method='ipw') ## nonparametric estimation with weights as inverse propensity score ps = predict(glm(A ~ X, family='binomial'), type='response') w = A/ps + (1-A)/(1-ps) fit2 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "natural", weights=w) ## Hypothetical strategy (removing intercurrent events), ## semiparametrically efficient estimation with covariates fit3 = surv.tteICE(A, bmt$t2, bmt$d4, "removed", X, method='eff')

text: Background Intercurrent events refer events occurring treatment initiation clinical trials affect either interpretation existence measurements associated clinical question interest. International Conference Harmonization (ICH) E9 (R1) addendum proposed five strategies address intercurrent events, namely, treatment policy strategy, composite variable strategy, treatment strategy, hypothetical strategy, principal stratum strategy. answer specific scientific question, strategy particular estimand chosen study design. Model adopt potential outcomes framework defines causal estimand contrast functionals potential outcomes. Consider randomized controlled trial \(n\) individuals randomly assigned one two treatment conditions, denoted \(w\), \(w = 1\) represents active treatment (test drug) \(w = 0\) represents control (placebo). Assume patients adhere treatment assignments discontinue treatment. Associated individual \(= 1, ..., n\) two potential time--event primary outcomes \(T_i(1)\) \(T_i(0)\), , represent time durations treatment initiation primary outcome event two treatment assignments respectively. Let \(R_i(1)\) \(R_i(0)\) denote occurrence time potential intercurrent events, , two treatment assignments, respectively. Intercurrent events considered absent post-treatment intercurrent events occur end study. Estimand adopt potential cumulative incidences treatment assignments target estimands. Potential cumulative incidences describe probability time--event outcomes occurring time point. define treatment effect contrast two potential cumulative incidences. Cumulative incidences model-free collapsible, enjoying causal interpretations. Formula specifications function typical model form Surv(time, status, type = "mstate")~ , status=0,1,2 (1 primary event, 2 intercurrent event, 0 censoring), treatment indicator (1 treatment 0 control). alternative model form cbind(Surv(time1, status1), Surv(time2, status2))~ , Surv(time1, status1) defines time status primary (terminal) event, Surv(time2, status2) defines time status intercurrent event. Baseline covariates can added model form ~ x1+x2

code: ## load data data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) X = as.matrix(bmt[,c('z1','z3','z5')]) bmt$A = A ## Composite variable strategy, ## nonparametric estimation without covariates  fit1 = tteICE(Surv.ice(t2, d4)~A, data=bmt, strategy="composite", method='eff') fit2 = tteICE(Surv.ice(t2, d4)~A, data=bmt, strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') fit20 = tteICE(Surv.ice(t1, d1)~A, data=bmt, strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') ## survival??  fit3 = tteICE(Surv.ice(t1,d1,t2,d2)~A, data=bmt, strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff')  fit30 = tteICE(Surv.ice(t2,d2,t1,d1)~A, data=bmt, strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') ## same results??

code: ## load data data(bmt) bmt = transform(bmt, d4=d2+d3) A = as.numeric(bmt$group>1) X = as.matrix(bmt[,c('z1','z3','z5')]) bmt$A = A library(survival) ## Composite variable strategy, ## nonparametric estimation without covariates  fit1 = tteICE2(Surv(t2, d4, type = "mstate")~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", method='eff') fit2 = tteICE2(Surv(t2, d4, type = "mstate")~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') fit20 = tteICE2(Surv(t2, d4)~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') #> Warning: Invalid status value, converted to NA  fit3 = tteICE2(cbind(Surv(t1, d1),Surv(t2,d2))~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff')  fit3 = tteICE2(cbind(Surv(t2, d2), Surv(t1,d1))~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') ## same results??  fit4 = tteICE2(Surv(t2, d2)~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff') fit5 = tteICE2(cbind(t1, d1,t2, d2)~A, data=bmt,  strategy="composite", cov.formula=~z1+z3+z5, method='eff')  ## also work
